video.title_en: The Earth Is Wobbling: The Precession of the Equinoxes

summary.text_en: Hipparchus is considered the greatest astronomer of antiquity. By comparing his own observations against older data (notably from Babylonian astronomers), he made a stunning discovery: the position of the equinoxes was slowly 'drifting' along the ecliptic. This is the 'Precession of the Equinoxes'. He also compiled the first scientific star catalog, listing the positions and brightness of ~850 stars, and invented the 'magnitude' system to classify their brightness levels.
key_points_en: Compiled the first scientific star catalog (~850 stars)
Refined astronomical models (e.g., epicycles) and instruments (e.g., astrolabe)

story.text_en: How did Hipparchus discover precession? He consulted centuries-old Babylonian and Alexandrian records (like those of Aristillus) of star positions relative to lunar eclipses. When he measured those same stars (notably Spica) from Rhodes, he found their positions relative to the equinox point had systematically shifted by about 2 degrees. He correctly deduced that it was not the stars that had moved, but that the entire coordinate system (the equinoxes) was slowly drifting 'backwards' against the backdrop of the stars. It was an incredibly subtle discovery that required precise measurement and a deep trust in historical data.

fun_facts.text_en: The stellar magnitude system we still use today (1st magnitude for brightest, 6th for faintest) was invented by Hipparchus. It's a logarithmic scale that successfully models human perception.
To turn astronomy from arithmetic (the Babylonian way) into geometry, Hipparchus invented trigonometry and created the first 'table of chords,' an early version of the modern sine function.

Hipparchus's own star catalog is lost. Most of what we know about it comes from Ptolemy, who used Hipparchus's data and methods as the core foundation for his own masterpiece, the 'Almagest', 250 years later.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine the Earth is a spinning top. As it spins, its axis (the 'point' pointing at the sky) doesn't stay perfectly still; it slowly wobbles in a big circle. The Earth does this too. This slow 'wobble' is called precession. Hipparchus was the first person to discover this wobble. It means that our 'North Star' (Polaris) was *not* the north star thousands of years ago, and in thousands of years, it won't be again. Hipparchus found this 26,000-year cycle by comparing ancient star charts to his own.

applications.text_en: He was the first to systematically apply the Babylonian 360-degree circle to geography, inventing the system of 'latitude' and 'longitude' we still use to map the Earth.

applications.text_en: The trigonometry (table of chords) he invented became the standard mathematical tool for calculating angles and distances in all science and engineering fields thereafter.

impact.text_en: Hipparchus transformed Greek astronomy from a philosophical pursuit into a rigorous, predictive, mathematical science based on observation. He set the gold standard for systematic observation, and his data and methods (precession, trigonometry) formed the core of all Western astronomy until the Copernican Revolution, 1,500 years later.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Provided the centuries of precise eclipse and planetary records necessary to discover precession
Aristarchus (for his early observations and heliocentric model, which Hipparchus calculated and refuted)

influenced.contribution_en: Ptolemy's 'Almagest' is almost entirely built upon the data, methods, and models of Hipparchus

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Hipparchus was the first true 'astronomical scientist', who replaced pure philosophical speculation with precise mathematics and systematic observation.

quiz.question_en: By comparing his own observations with ancient Babylonian records, what major astronomical phenomenon did Hipparchus discover?
options_en: That the Sun was the center of the universe
quiz.explanation_en: Only by comparing precise data separated by hundreds of years could the extremely slow, systematic drift of 'precession' be noticed. This was Hipparchus's greatest achievement.
